prescription_defaults.notes: Tendon glides + open/close pulses + wrist circles. Goal: warmth and readiness, not pump. Stay easy.
Tempo: 3-1-1.
Short controlled pulls, not max.

exercises.name: Easy Dead Hangs (Warm-up)

prescription_defaults.notes: Very easy intensity.

exercises.description: Low-intensity dead hangs used as warm-up or tendon conditioning. Builds blood flow and prepares fingers without fatigue.
cues: Use large comfortable edge
Shoulders engaged, body still
Conversational effort (RPE 4-5)
Breathe normally
Perfect for daily use or rehab

exercises.name: Max Hang (5s)
exercises.description: Short-duration maximum-weight hangs for peak neural recruitment and finger flexor strength (López/Hörst MaxHangs MAW short variant).
cues: Choose edge/weight you can hold 7-8s max
Hang exactly 5s — not to failure
Shoulders engaged, elbows slightly forward
Add weight in 2.5-5kg increments
Fully warmed up (15-20 min progressive)

exercises.name: Max Hang (7s)
exercises.description: 7-second near-maximal hangs for maximum finger strength and neural drive (Hörst/López protocol).
cues: Edge/weight you can hold exactly 10s max
Hang precisely 7 seconds
Shoulders packed, body completely still
53-second rest optimizes PCr recovery
Last set should be very hard but perfect form

exercises.name: Bechtel 3-6-9 Ladder

prescription_defaults.notes: Progressive ladder WITHIN each set: 3s → rest 10-30s → 6s → rest → 9s (optional 12s). 3-5 full ladders per grip position.

exercises.description: Steve Bechtel’s 3-6-9 Ladders: progressive duration hangs within each set to build maximum finger strength with built-in recovery.
cues: Edge you can hold 8-12s max
3s → short rest → 6s → short rest → 9s (opt 12s)
Adjust inter-hang rest based on recovery
3-5 full ladders per grip (half-crimp, open, pinch)
3-5 min rest between full ladder sets

exercises.name: Hangboard Repeaters 7/3 (Strength-Endurance)

prescription_defaults.notes: Aim ~60–75% max hang load; stop before form breaks. Protocol: 7s_on/3s_off.

exercises.description: Classic Anderson Brothers / Hörst repeater protocol for finger strength-endurance: trains anaerobic capacity and lactate tolerance with 42s TUT per set.
cues: 60-80% MVC (finish all 6 reps but pumped)
Strict 7s on / 3s off timing
Shoulders active, no dead hang
Half-crimp primary, alternate grips across sets
If you drop before rep 6, reduce load

exercises.name: Hörst 7-53 Protocol

prescription_defaults.notes: 90-95% intensity. Each set = 3 hangs (7s on / 53s off). 3 min between sets. Hörst signature protocol.

exercises.description: The signature Hörst 7-53 protocol builds maximum finger strength and neural drive through short, near-maximal isometric hangs with precise phosphocreatine recovery timing.
cues: Choose edge/weight you can hold exactly 10s max
Hang exactly 7s (not to failure)
Shoulders packed, body still, no kipping
53s rest = full PCr resynthesis
Last set should feel very hard but form perfect

exercises.name: Repeater Hang 15/15 (IntHangs)

prescription_defaults.notes: 4-5 reps, 7-10s work. Eva López IntHangs standard protocol.

exercises.description: Eva López Intermittent Hangs (IntHangs) protocol for strength-endurance: medium intensity repeated hangs with short rest.
cues: Strict timing: 10s on / 15s off
Half-crimp primary
Finish all reps with good form
TUT per set ~40-50s

exercises.name: Density Hangs (Tyler Nelson)

prescription_defaults.notes: 20-40s to near-failure. Open-hand preferred.

exercises.description: Tyler Nelson’s Density Hangs protocol for tendon hypertrophy, stress-shielding and forearm muscle density via long-duration near-failure hangs.
cues: Open-hand grip preferred
Hang 20-40s to ~95% RPE (near failure)
2-3 reps per grip, 3-5 min rest
Choose edge you can hold 20-45s bodyweight
Elbows extended, focus on tendon health

exercises.name: Long Duration Hang (Tendon Health)

prescription_defaults.notes: Large edge (25-35mm). 30-45s hangs. Low intensity, focus on tissue loading and injury prevention.

exercises.description: Long-duration hangs (30+ seconds) at moderate intensity for tendon conditioning, injury prevention and structural adaptation (Lattice protocol).
cues: Large comfortable hold
30-70% intensity (conversational)
Continuous hang, no reps
90s-2min rest between sets
Excellent for warm-up or rehab

exercises.name: Minimum Edge Hang (MED)

prescription_defaults.notes: Bodyweight only. Minimum edge = smallest edge you can hold for 15s at bodyweight. 3 min rest between hangs, 5 min between full sets.

exercises.description: Minimum Edge (MED) protocol for structural tendon adaptation and small-edge specificity. Hang exactly 12 seconds on the smallest edge you can hold for ~15 seconds bodyweight only.
cues: Find edge you can barely hold 15s max
Hang precisely 12s (3s safety margin)
Full bodyweight — no added load
Shoulders packed, body still
Progress by reducing edge depth week-to-week

exercises.name: Pinch Block Training

prescription_defaults.notes: Loadable pinch block. Progress via added weight. Full thumb wrap.

exercises.description: Hörst pinch-grip repeater training to strengthen thumb-lock and closed-crimp positions using a pinch block.
cues: Use Tension Block or Lattice Quad
7-second hangs strict timing
6 reps per hand per set
Add weight via loading pin
Thumb fully locked

exercises.name: One-Arm Hang (Assisted)

prescription_defaults.notes: One arm with pulley or band assistance. 20mm edge. Half crimp. Advanced only.

exercises.description: Advanced one-arm hang protocol (Cameron Hörst) for unilateral finger strength using assistance to reduce bodyweight.
cues: Use pulley system or band
5-10 second hangs
Prevent body spinning
Shoulder stable and packed
Progress by reducing assistance

exercises.name: López Submaximal Hangs

prescription_defaults.notes: 30-40% max load. High volume, low intensity. Eva López protocol for tendon conditioning.

exercises.description: Eva López Submaximal Hangs for strength-endurance and aerobic power: long hangs at 55-85% MVC with progressive rest reduction.
cues: Single continuous hang 20-45s per set
Near-failure at end of TUT
Rest starts long (180s) and decreases to 30s over weeks
Half-crimp primary
Excellent for hypertrophy without max intensity

exercises.name: Critical Force Test

prescription_defaults.notes: 7s on / 3s off to failure at fixed load. Determines aerobic threshold of forearm.

exercises.description: Scientific 3-stage all-out test to determine finger flexor critical force (CF) and W' (Giles et al. / Lattice).
cues: Requires force gauge (Tindeq)
Stage 1: 80% MVC to failure
Stage 2: 60% MVC immediately
Stage 3: 45% MVC immediately
Record time to failure each stage

exercises.name: Maximum Effort Duration Test (MED)

prescription_defaults.notes: Hang at 45% bodyweight until failure. Record total seconds.

exercises.description: Lattice Maximum Effort Duration test: single continuous hang at 45% MVC to failure to assess finger endurance capacity.
cues: 45% of MVC-7
Continuous hang to absolute failure
Record exact seconds
Use for tracking endurance progress
Typically 60-300s for trained climbers

prescription_defaults.notes: Very low pump. Continuous movement. If pump rises, downgrade.
Silent feet, no readjust, hip-in, breathing. Keep it easy.
Rings, low bar, or TRX. Easier than pullup. Great for shoulder health.
Can use parallel bars or rings.
Parallettes removed in v1; floor variant only.
Dynamic flow: thoracic rotations, arm circles, scapular CARs. No static stretching.
Light jogging in place + arm swings.
Controlled ladders, avoid cutting feet.
Half crimp. No skipping rungs. Sprint speed. Stop when speed drops.
Feet on wall for assistance. Good intermediate progression. Focus on contact quality.
Touch-and-go on higher rung, one arm at a time. Focus explosive contact.
Advanced only. 5+ years climbing minimum. Double dyno on campus. Full rest between sets.
3-7 moves at limit. Focus deadpoint and latching. Full rest. Stop when quality drops.
Also works on Moon Board, Tension Board. 3-5 attempts per problem, full rest between.
Explosive pull, hands leave the bar. Full rest. Quality over quantity.
Choose grade where you fail on rep 3-4. Not rep 1-2 (too hard) or complete all 4 easily (too easy).
Link 3-5 boulders without pause. Moderate grade. Rest fully between sets.
Climb route sections with timed rest. Grade 1-2 below onsight. Focus sustained effort.
Well below onsight grade. Zero pump. If you feel pump, go easier.
Just below onsight grade. Sustained effort. Moderate pump acceptable.
Grade VERY far below onsight. Must feel trivially easy. Chat-pace effort. Lattice 5x3 style.
Repeated laps on easy routes. Focus recovery, blood flow, and movement quality.
Easy traverses, 15-20 min continuous. Zero pump. Focus fluid movement.
Added weight via belt or vest. Progress load, not reps.
Maintain L-sit throughout. If core fails first, reduce reps.
Asymmetric pullup. Alternate sides. One arm pulls, other assists on bar.
Hold 5-10s at each angle. 90°, 120°, full lock. 3-5 sets per angle.
Band or pulley assistance. Advanced. Focus controlled full ROM.
Barbell or dumbbell row. Controlled eccentric.
Pull to top, traverse laterally at top position. Alternate direction.
Instability from rings increases demand. Turn rings out at top.
Also excellent as prehab. 3-4 sets, 15-20 reps.
Tuck, advanced tuck, or one-leg. Progress toward full. Maintain hollow body.
Straight legs to bar. Control the negative. No kipping.
Ab wheel recommended; towel on smooth floor works too.
Press and hold. Resist rotation. Alternate sides.
Each side. Stack feet or stagger. Hips high.
Slow and controlled. Press low back into floor. Breathe out on extension.
Controlled rotation. Legs to bar, rotate side to side.
Strict form. No kipping. Full compression at top.
Light dumbbell. Slow and controlled. Forearm on knee.
Light dumbbell. Slow and controlled. Forearm on knee, palm down.
Hammer or light dumbbell. Slow and controlled.
Rubber band around fingers. 3-4 sets, 15-20 reps. Daily if desired.
Slow eccentric. Key exercise for elbow tendinopathy prevention. Tyler twist / reverse Tyler twist.
Full range. Slow and controlled. 3 reps each direction per arm.
Climb well below onsight. Focus: zero noise on footplacements.
Place foot once, no adjustment. Forces precision. Well below onsight grade.
Climb up, climb down controlled. Every route/boulder. Builds eccentric strength and awareness.
Count to 3 between every move. Forces reading, breathing, and deliberate movement.
Inside flag, outside flag, drop knee practice. Easy boulders. Focus body tension and balance.

exercises.name: Breathing Awareness

prescription_defaults.notes: Climb easy problems focusing only on breath rhythm. Inhale on setup, exhale on hard moves. Notice when you hold your breath and correct.

exercises.description: Conscious breathing drill during easy climbing to build automatic breath-movement coordination. Reduces oxygen debt and tension on harder routes by training diaphragmatic breathing under low-intensity climbing load (Husbands-Bosworth relaxation principle).
cues: Climb 2-3 grades below max on easy terrain
Inhale through nose during setup moves, exhale through mouth on effort
Pause at each rest position and take 2-3 deep belly breaths
Notice any breath-holding and consciously release
Shake out arms while breathing deeply at every good hold

exercises.name: Foothold Stare Drill

prescription_defaults.notes: Watch your foot contact the hold and stay watching until fully weighted. Do not look away until weight is committed.

exercises.description: Visual tracking drill to eliminate sloppy foot placements. Force yourself to watch each foot all the way onto the hold and not look away until fully weighted. Builds the neural pathway for precise, confident footwork (Hörst precision footwork method).
cues: Eyes track foot from selection to placement to weighting
Do not look away until full weight is on the foot
Place toe precisely on the best part of the hold
Climb 2-3 grades below max to maintain focus
Zero readjustments allowed after initial placement

exercises.name: Hip Rotation Drill

prescription_defaults.notes: On every move, consciously rotate hips toward the wall. Turn hip of reaching hand into the wall before initiating the reach.

exercises.description: Deliberate hip turn-in drill to build automatic hip rotation on steep terrain. Rotating the hip into the wall shifts centre of gravity closer to feet, reduces arm load, and extends reach (Hörst twist-lock / hip-turn principle).
cues: Before each reach, rotate the same-side hip toward the wall
Lead with the hip, not the hand
Feel weight shift onto the outside edge of the opposite foot
Exaggerate the rotation on easy terrain to build the pattern
Combine with drop-knee on steep sections

exercises.name: Hover Hands

prescription_defaults.notes: Hover hand 2-3cm above next hold for a full second before grabbing. Forces deliberate movement and eliminates lunging.

exercises.description: Movement quality drill where each hand must hover above the target hold for one full second before grabbing it. Eliminates grabby, rushed movement and builds controlled, deliberate reaching (Husbands-Bosworth precision reaching method).
cues: Reach to the hold but stop 2-3cm short and hover
Hold the hover position for a full second
Only then close the hand and grip the hold
Maintain stable body position during the hover
If you lunge or grab immediately, repeat the move

exercises.name: One Hand Climbing

prescription_defaults.notes: Climb easy problems using only one hand. Alternate left and right each rep. Forces extreme reliance on footwork, balance, and body positioning.

exercises.description: Constraint drill where one hand is kept behind the back while climbing easy terrain. Massively amplifies dependence on footwork, hip position, and balance. Builds body awareness and foot trust by removing the compensation of the second hand (differential learning method).
cues: Keep one hand behind your back or in a chalk bag
Climb very easy problems (4+ grades below max)
Place feet with extreme precision — they are your lifeline
Use hip shifts and body tension to stay in balance
Alternate lead hand each problem

exercises.name: Sloth / Monkey Move

prescription_defaults.notes: Alternate between ultra-slow (sloth) and fast-dynamic (monkey) on the same easy problem. Builds tempo awareness and movement versatility.

exercises.description: Tempo contrast drill alternating between extremely slow, controlled climbing (sloth) and fast, dynamic movement (monkey) on the same easy problem. Develops movement versatility, tempo awareness, and the ability to shift gears between static and dynamic styles (differential learning method).
cues: Sloth mode: move as slowly as physically possible, minimum 5s per move
Monkey mode: climb fluidly and quickly with minimal pauses
Same problem, back to back — sloth then monkey
Maintain perfect technique in both modes
Notice which mode feels harder and train that more

exercises.name: Sticky Feet Drill

prescription_defaults.notes: Place feet with zero noise. If you hear your shoe touch the hold, repeat the placement. Train precise, deliberate foot contact.

exercises.description: Precision footwork drill where every foot placement must be completely silent. Any audible contact with the hold means the placement was imprecise and must be repeated. Builds proprioceptive awareness and eliminates sloppy, stamped placements (Hörst quiet-feet principle).
cues: Place each foot with zero audible contact on the hold
If you hear any noise, pull the foot back and re-place
Watch your foot all the way onto the hold
Climb 2-3 grades below max to maintain focus
Focus on toe tip precision, not full-foot smearing

exercises.name: Straight Arms Drill

prescription_defaults.notes: Climb with arms as straight as possible at all times. Only bend to pull through the move, then immediately straighten. Builds skeletal hanging habit.

exercises.description: Body position drill forcing straight-arm climbing to build the habit of hanging on skeleton rather than muscles. Keeping arms extended reduces bicep fatigue and shifts load to the stronger skeletal system (Hörst straight-arm climbing principle).
cues: Keep arms fully extended whenever not actively moving
Only bend arms to execute a move, then straighten immediately
Sink hips low and away from the wall on vertical terrain
Use hip turns and high steps to keep arms long on steep terrain
If you notice bent arms at rest, shake out and reset

exercises.name: Tap and Place

prescription_defaults.notes: Tap the target foothold gently with your toe, lift away, then place precisely. The tap forces you to rehearse the placement before committing.

exercises.description: Footwork precision drill where you tap each foothold lightly with your toe before placing your foot on it. The tap rehearsal prevents rushed placements and trains the foot-eye coordination pathway for accurate first-attempt contact (Climbing Research precision footwork protocol).
cues: Lightly tap the foothold with your toe tip first
Lift your foot back off after the tap
Now place with full precision and weight the foot
Zero readjustments after the final placement
Maintain focus even when pumped or tired

exercises.name: Three Limb Drill

prescription_defaults.notes: Climb using only 3 contact points at any time. Before grabbing a new hold, release one limb. Forces deliberate sequencing and balance awareness.

exercises.description: Constraint drill where only three limbs may contact the wall at any time. Before establishing a new contact, one limb must be released first. Builds deliberate move sequencing, balance awareness, and body tension under reduced support (differential learning constraint method).
cues: Maximum 3 points of contact at any time
Plan each move: decide which limb to release before reaching
Maintain body tension through the transition
Use flagging and hip shifts to stay balanced on 3 points
Climb easy problems — focus on control, not difficulty

prescription_defaults.notes: Hold each position 45-60s. Breathe deeply. Post-session or rest day.
Pec stretch, cross-body, sleeper stretch. Hold 45-60s each.
Essential after every climbing session. 2-3 min minimum. Wrist extension and flexion on floor.
Yin-yoga inspired. Hips, shoulders, spine, hamstrings. Hold 60s+ per position.
High step drill, hip CARs, active frog. Dynamic, controlled movement.
Belly-to-wall. Arms straight, shoulders elevated. 3-4 x 20-30s.
Walk up from pushup position to handstand at wall. Controlled descent.
In handstand at wall, tap opposite shoulder. Anti-rotation + stability.
Skill practice. Many short attempts, full rest. Quality over quantity.
Wall-supported HSPU. Full ROM. Head to floor. Control the negative.
Jump rope recommended but optional. Good pulse raiser alternative.
Kettlebell or dumbbell. Alternate sides. Slow and controlled. Full body coordination.
Heavy dumbbells or kettlebells. Walk with control. Suitcase carry for anti-lateral flexion.
Quadrupedia. Shoulder stability + coordination. Knees off ground. Slow and controlled.
Can do daily. 2-3 sets of 15-20. Essential for shoulder health.
Project-level routes. Full rest between attempts. Focus on linking crux sequences.
Flexor and extensor stretches. Prayer and reverse prayer. Hold each side.
Each side. Keep hips square. Breathe into the stretch.
Knees wide, hips sink toward floor. Gentle hold, no bouncing.
Doorway stretch or wall pec stretch. Each side. Open chest and anterior shoulder.
Soft knees. Hang heavy. Breathe and relax into the stretch.
Each side. Knees stacked, arms wide. Let gravity do the work.
Heels down. Hold a support if needed. Open hips and thoracic spine.
Alternating sides. Full depth. Heel stays down on working leg.
Supine. Use hip flexors to raise straight leg. Hold 2s at top. Each side.
Seated. Knees at 90 degrees. Rotate from one side to the other with control.

exercises.name: Max Hang 10s (Hypertrophy)

prescription_defaults.notes: 85-90% intensity. Longer duration for structural/hypertrophic adaptation.

exercises.description: Extended-duration maximum-weight hangs (10 seconds) targeting structural tendon adaptation and finger flexor hypertrophy. The longer hang time shifts the training stimulus from pure neural recruitment toward connective tissue remodeling (López/Eva López long-duration variant).
cues: Choose edge/weight you can hold for exactly 13-14s max
Hang precisely 10 seconds — do not hang to failure
Shoulders engaged and packed, elbows slightly bent
Body completely still — no swinging or kipping
3-minute rest between sets for full phosphocreatine recovery

prescription_defaults.notes: Touch high rung and return. Focus on speed and precision. Contact strength development.
Advanced. 1-4-7, 1-5-8 patterns. Full body tension. Stop when speed drops. Anderson RCTM / Hörst.
Match on rung, rapid hand switches (hand-over-hand). Speed training. Same rung height throughout.
Up and down repeatedly for 15-20s. Alactic-aerobic campus capacity. Stop if form breaks.
Every Minute On the Minute. Start at minute mark, rest remainder. Grade at flash or +1. 10-15 minutes total.
On The Minute (every 2 min). Grade at or above flash level. Longer rest than EMOM allows harder attempts.
Link 3-5 boulders back-to-back, no rest between. Grade 2-3 below flash. 5 min rest between circuits.
Start at 15 min continuous, build to 30 min week over week. Grade well below onsight. Zero pump target.
120s climb / 60s rest. Moderate pump OK, deep pump = too hard. RPE 7-8/10. Hörst recommended protocol.
Grade 4-6 below onsight. Conversational pace. 20-30 min. Focus on movement quality, not effort.
